John R. Gerlach

Age 79 of Bellevue passed away on Sunday, January 14, 2024. Born on February 28, 1944 and was the son of the late John and Lauretta Gerlach.

While attending St. Joseph Grade School in the Manchester section of Pittsburgh, Jack began taking piano lessons from Sister Gregory, a Benedictine Nun. He became proficient at the keyboard and was encouraged to consider learning to play the pipe organ at the parish church. From then on, he excelled in church music, including Gregorian Chant, Latin Mass Propers, and traditional and modern hymns.

John was a member of the Bellevue Council 1400 Knights of Columbus and dedicated his life to providing beautiful inspiring music for many churches in the Pittsburgh Diocese. He continued sharing his talent for over 50 years.

He had a special place in his heart for Sacred Heart Parish in Emsworth where he was an organist for 41 years.

Survived by his classmates and Friends, Francis J. Naderhoff and Emil Payer. In addition to his parents, he is preceded in death by his grandmother Didi Henderson.

Family and Friends will be received on Friday January 19, 2024 from 2:00pm to 6:00pm at the McDonald-Linn Funeral Home, 529 California Ave., Avalon, PA 15202. A Funeral Mass will be held on Saturday at 11:00AM at Sacred Heart Church-Regina Coeli Parish. Interment will be private.

Age 86, of Avalon, passed away Tuesday, November 30, 2021. He was born January 13, 1935, in Ambridge to the late Pietro and Carmela (Rovini) Fardo. Jack settled in Avalon and was well known in the North Boro's community. Those who worked with him and knew him, understood what a generous man he was. JAMES P. HOLDCROFT

On Wednesday, July 21st, James P. Holdcroft of Ohio Township passed away rather unexpectedly despite his 93 years of age at UPMC Passavant Hospital with his family by his side. A member of the Bellevue Knights of Columbus. He was chronically young for his age. Jim, as he was most commonly known, was happily married for over 50 years to the love of his life, the late Ruth Anne Holdcroft. He was father of Kathryn Holdcroft Cauley, James P. Holdcroft, Jr. (Sara Maddern Holdcroft), and Kimberly Holdcroft and the last surviving sibling of the late Helen Fitzpatrick, Edward Holdcroft, Margaret Birsic, Mary Lou Roos, Robert, Paul and Daniel Holdcroft. Jim was the proud grandfather of Kimberly Cauley Eckel (Ryan Eckel) and Fiona Holdcroft Lynch (David Lynch) and great-grandfather of Asher Cauley Eckel, Eliot James Eckel and Sage Ruthanne Eckel. Jim was also the loving companion and aide-de-camp of his four-legged friends, Paddy, Buddy and Rusty. Jim served in the Navy during WWII. While in the Navy he was a Golden Gloves boxing champion and was trained and mentored by Joe Louis. Once home, he began his 40-year career helping others achieve better lives as union organizer, representative and highly effective negotiator. Jim loved life. Everything he did, he did with enthusiastic energy, joy, and integrity. Jim always believed that if something were worth doing it was worth doing well – and he was always doing something. For decades Jim was an active organic gardener who would joyfully spend endless hours outside planning and executing new projects, tending flower beds, pruning his many shrubs and bushes, and growing some of the best tomatoes around. Family and friends who visited Jim were usually always first greeted with a personally guided tour of his gardens which included an update on the latest developments for each of his favorite plants. Jim was an avid reader and a keen student of economics and politics. He relished a good conversation and thoughtful debate. Jim was a deeply religious man who was active in his church and happily put his faith into action. He was exceedingly generous of his time and money with those in need. Jim will be remembered most, however, for the great love he had for his family and his friends. For Jim, family started with his brothers and sisters, and rapidly expanded to their spouses and their children and on from there. His circle of family and friends was ever expanding. Finally, it should be noted that Jim was the undisputed champion bedtime storyteller for three generations with an unmatched ability to revise the classics to incorporate the doings and antics of whichever child, grandchild or great-grandchild that needed some comforting. Jim left a legacy for all who knew him by the example of his ways. His humor, his grace, and charm live on in the hearts of all he loved. Friends and family will be received from 1-3 p.m. and 5-7 p.m. on August 6th at LAWRENCE T. MILLER FUNERAL HOME, INC., 460 Lincoln Ave., Bellevue. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 10 a.m. on August 7th at Sacred Heart Church, 154 Orchard Ave., Emsworth. Interment to follow at Highwood Cemetery, 2800 Brighton Rd., Pittsburgh.

George John Jakabcsin

81, of Ross Township, joined our Heavenly Father on Sunday, October 11, 2020. He was being cared for at UPMC Passavant Hospital in the North Hills, and he passed with his loving wife by his side. He was born November 8, 1938, in Pittsburgh, PA, to George and Anna Jakabcsin. In 1965, he married his beautiful bride, Mary. She is still with us and continues to be the matriarch of his wonderful and warmhearted family. Also, surviving are his three sons, daughters-in-law, and grandchildren, Paul and Pamela (Alexander) Jakabcsin of Ann Arbor, MI; Mark and Ingrid (Schawaller) Jakabcsin of Jacksonville Beach, FL; and John and Deirdre (Berry) Jakabcsin of West Chicago, IL; and five grandchildren, Haley Jakabcsin, Nicole Jakabcsin, Eric Jakabcsin, Benjamin Jakabcsin, and Bridget Jakabcsin. George's mother and father preceded him in death. George was a proud graduate of North Catholic High School in 1956 and Duquesne University in 1960 with a degree in accounting. Following his college graduation, he entered the U.S. Navy, served on the USS Earle B. Hall during the Cuban Missile Crisis, and later served on the USS Kirwin. After military service, he began his professional career working as an executive in accounting and finance. He worked in retailing for years, including at Gimbels in Pittsburgh and at May Co. stores in Youngstown, Ohio and Pittsburgh. George had also been the CFO of Pittsburgh Brewing, Busy Beaver, and Giant Eagle. Later he started his own accounting and consulting firm. While maintaining his professional career, George also served in the U.S. Navy Reserve and rose to the rank of Lieutenant Commander. George's life centered on two key passions - family and fishing. He enjoyed watching his children and grandchildren grow and develop into intelligent, caring individuals. He also loved to fish. Any time that he could sneak away to make a few casts into the water was a wonderful time. That was increased when he could have family alongside him at the water's edge. George was a devout Catholic and an active member of his parish, St. Sebastian in the North Hills. He was also a member of the Bellevue Council 1400 Knights of Columbus. He and his wife attended services regularly, and there is no question that God and Jesus Christ were his guide and his light. Burial will be at the National Cemetery of the Alleghenys. There is no visitation scheduled at this time, but a memorial for George will be held after the Covid-19 threat has ended. Memorial contributions may be made to St. Sebastian Parish.
